title: Caramelized French Toast
description: This isn't your ordinary French toast - it's a game-changing recipe that solves all the common French toast problems: no more soggy centers, no scrambled egg edges, and a perfectly caramelized exterior that adds an incredible crunch. The secret lies in using only egg yolks, cooking low and slow, and a final caramelization step that takes this breakfast favorite to new heights.

base.text: 1 loaf challah or brioche bread (or 8-10 thick sliced white bread)
base.name: challah or brioche bread

base.text: 1 1/2 cups heavy cream (or half & half if you must)
base.name: heavy cream

instructions.text: If using a whole loaf, slice the bread into thick slices (about 1-inch thick). Let the bread sit out for a few hours or overnight to get slightly stale - this helps it absorb the custard better.
In a large shallow bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, heavy cream, sugar, vanilla, salt, cinnamon, and nutmeg until well combined.
Soak each slice of bread in the egg mixture for 5-7 minutes per side. This longer soak time allows the bread to fully absorb the custard.
Heat a large skillet or griddle over medium-low heat. Add equal parts butter and oil (this prevents burning while maintaining flavor).
Cook the soaked bread for about 3-4 minutes per side, or until golden brown. The key is cooking on medium-low - it takes longer but ensures a fully cooked, fluffy center.

For the caramelization: Sprinkle additional granulated sugar on each side of the cooked French toast. Return to the pan and cook until the sugar melts and caramelizes, about 1 minute per side. Add a small pat of butter under each slice to help the sugar caramelize evenly.
Serve immediately while the caramelized sugar is still crispy. Optional toppings: maple syrup, powdered sugar, fresh berries, or caramelized bananas.

notes: BREAD CHOICE IS CRUCIAL: Brioche or challah are ideal, but any thick-cut bread will work. The bread should be slightly stale.
EGG YOLKS ONLY: Using only yolks (no whites) prevents the scrambled egg edges that often plague French toast.
LONG SOAK TIME: Don't rush the soaking process - 5-7 minutes per side allows the bread to fully absorb the custard.
LOW AND SLOW: Cooking on medium-low takes longer but ensures perfectly cooked centers.
MAKE AHEAD: You can prepare and cook the French toast ahead of time. When reheating, sprinkle with fresh sugar and re-caramelize for the best texture.
